questionListItems.title: What are the possible side effects?

answer.body:
The vaccine has been assessed to be safe for use.
However, you may experience common side effects, similar to other vaccines. Most side effects are mild or moderate, and usually get better within a few days.

The table below lists some common side effects that have been reported with this vaccine, and how to manage them.

Side Effects

How to Manage

Pain, redness, swelling at the injection site


Fever, chills


Headache, muscle pain, joint pain

Those with fever are advised to self-isolate at home until the fever subsides.


Paracetamol 1 to 2 tablets for the other side effects every 6 hours for adults or dosed accordingly to the child's weight as needed.


Tiredness

Rest

Lymph node swelling at neck or arms

Usually gets better by itself in a week or so


See a doctor if:

 

  • The side effects persist or get worse.

  • The fever persists for more than 48 hours (2 days).

  • Respiratory symptoms such as cough, runny nose, sore throat, shortness of breath or loss of sense of taste and smell develop.

  • Heart or chest symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath or abnormal heart beats develop.


In very rare cases, this vaccine can cause a severe allergic reaction. Signs of a severe allergic reaction include difficulty breathing, swelling of your face, throat, eyes or lips, a fast heartbeat, dizziness and weakness, a bad rash all over your body. 

If you experience a severe allergic reaction, seek medical attention immediately. Call 995 or go to the nearest A&E immediately.

questionListItems.title: Where can I find out more about the COVID-19 vaccines?

answer.body: Learn more about COVID-19 vaccines by visiting the MOH website.

questionListItems.title: I received msg to book appointment for my HPV2 Vaccination. But I’m not in Singapore until 28th July. Can I book when I’m back? There was no slot to book after June

answer.body:
Appointments offered on HAS are currently only up to 30 days in advance. You can definitely book an appointment when you're back in Singapore.

As long as your first dose of the HPV vaccine is taken before your 27th birthday, you can still benefit from the subsidies. Do refer to the subsidies section on the HPV2 booking page (book.health.gov.sg/hpv) for more information.

questionListItems.title: What is the duration of each appointment slot?

answer.body:
The duration of each appointment slot is 30 minutes. If your clinic's opening hours are from 12pm to 2pm, available slots will be shown as 12pm, 12:30 pm, 1pm, and 1:30 pm.
Each slot is reserved for one patient only.

It’s a free queue management system inside HAS that is designed specifically for GP clinics. It aims to provide your walk-ins and appointment patients with an amazing wait experience: being able to queue remotely.

How? By giving patients a real-time view of their queue status, and reminding them to come back to the clinic via SMSes. If you’re constantly yelling out patients’ names outside your clinic, or have angry patients harassing your clinic assistants, Queue is for you.

questionListItems.title: Does my clinic have to pay for Queue?

answer.body: No. HAS, Queue, and all SMSes are free for the foreseeable future.

questionListItems.title: My clinic has a TV screen, can I display the current queue number for patients?

answer.body: Yes, Queue provides a TV screen view which allows you to display the queue for patients who are physically waiting in your clinic.

questionListItems.title: Is it integrated with my CMS?

answer.body: While it’s in our longer term roadmap to integrate with the top CMSes (Hummingbird, Plato, GPC, CA), HAS (and Queue) runs in parallel with your CMS. Nevertheless, the team has gone to great lengths to ensure that registration of patients onto Queue is fast and painless.

questionListItems.title: Where can I find out more about Healthier SG?

answer.body: Visit healthiersg.gov.sg or call 6325 9220 for more details

questionListItems.title: hi, if my first dose is free under the temasek programme thingy/because i have the orange chas card, does this mean the 2nd and 3rd dose are free as well?

answer.body: Yes, the second and third doses will be free if your appointments are also booked at a Temasek Foundation (TF) and The Singapore Cancer Society (SCS) (TF-SCS) partner clinic since you've taken the first dose before the age of 27.

The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination prevents specific types of HPV infections that may lead to cervical cancer. HPV vaccination is recommended for females aged 9 to 26 years. Government subsidies for HPV2 are available for eligible female Singaporeans at CHAS GP clinics and polyclinics.

questionListItems.title: When would I get to be invited for a flu jab? Where to check?

answer.body:
SMS invitations for vaccinations are currently only sent to members of the public within the recommended age range. You can still book an appointment for flu vaccination via book.health.gov.sg without an SMS invitation.
Do check out the eligibility criteria for subsidies before booking an appointment.

questionListItems.title: I have completed my HPV vaccination when I am 16 years old. Do I require to take again when I am 25 years old now?

answer.body: Since you have already completed the HPV vaccination course, there is no need to take another dose or repeat the course again.

questionListItems.title: If i Book my first HPV dose, through the booking system at a certain clinic, for the subsequent doses, do I have to continue going to that specific clinic? or can i change a clinic?

answer.body: You can visit a different clinic for your follow up HPV vaccination doses. However, please highlight to the new GP regarding your previous vaccination so that they can refer to your vaccination record.

questionListItems.title: not sure if i’m vaccinated
questionListItems.body: how do i know if i’m vaccinated

answer.body:
Singaporeans who are born in 1996 or later are able to access their vaccination records via HealthHub with their Singpass.

 
Those who are born earlier (i.e. before 1996) are also able to access their vaccination records via HealthHub. However, records are only available for vaccinations under the National Adult Immunisation Schedule (NAIS), which were given on or after 1 Nov 2017, and notified accordingly.
 
To view your immunisation records in HealthHub, login and click onServices > Health Records > Immunisation Records > Nationally Recommended.
